questions.question_text: In which two situations should you assign an alias? (Choose two.)

choices.D: To assign an alternative name to a value in a measure
choices.B: To rename all the data values in a field
choices.A: To assign an alternative name to a value in a dimension field
choices.C: To supplement data in a primary data source with data from a secondary data source

comments.content: nevermind . It can be applied to a measure as well

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AB
It can't be D. A measure is generally a continuous or discrete number. you can't have an alternative alias to a continuous or discrete number

Selected Answer: AD
A&D is correct

comments.content: B is incorrect. Correct answer is A & D

choices.B: A workbook connected to a live connection will have fresher data than a workbook connected to an extract.
choices.C: A live connection reduces the amount of memory used on a client computer as compared to an extract.
choices.D: A live connection is always faster than an extract.
choices.A: A live connection to a database server requires less network overhead than an extract.

questions.question_text: What are two benefits of using a live connection to a data source as compared to an extract? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BC
B&C is correct

questions.question_text: Which two functionalities can you provide to consumers by adding a parameter to a visualization? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Change the results of calculations in the visualization.
choices.D: Create a new field in the data source.
choices.B: Download the underlying data as a CSV file.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A&C is correct

questions.question_text: What are two requirements to combine two tables by using a union? (Choose two.)

choices.C: The tables must come from different connections.
choices.B: Related fields must have different names.
choices.A: Related fields must have matching data types.
choices.D: The tables must have the same number of fields.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
Technically D is not correct. You can have a different number of fields, the unmatched fields will have lots of nulls in them. From their documentation: "For best results, the tables that you combine using a union must have the same structure. That is, each table must have the same number of fields, and related fields must have matching field names and data types."

Selected Answer: AD
A&D is correct

Selected Answer: C
C is correct
The correct answer is C. If you drop a measure in either rows or columns, automatically gets a bar plot

Selected Answer: C
tried in Tableau, stacked bars need 1 or more dimensions & 1 or more measures; highlight table needs 1 or more dimensions and 1 measure; bars need 0 or more dimensions and 1 or more measures; treemap needs 1 or more dimensions and 1 or 2 measures.

Selected Answer: B
B is correct because this type of chart can be created with just measures and does not necessarily require a dimension. It displays values in a grid format where cells are colored based on the measure values, allowing the focus to be purely on the measure itself.

questions.question_text: Which type of chart can you create without using a dimension?
